definition.iso_639_3_eng: Reference to the term that represents the namespace of the current term.

description.iso_639_3_eng:
*Namespaces* are used to *group* terms under the same *category* or *classification*, the value of this property is the [global identifier](gid.md) of the *term* that *represents* the *namespace* of the *current term*.

Namespaces are also used to *disambiguate* [local identifiers](lid.md): *local identifiers* must be *unique* within the same *namespace*.

*Most* terms will have a namespace, but this property is *not required*: terms that do not have a namespace are usually used as top level namespaces.

Any term's [global identifier](gid.md) can be used as a *namespace*.

examples.iso_639_3_eng:
```json
{
	"term_code": {
		"nid": "iso_3166_1",
		"lid": "ITA",
		"gid": "iso_3166_1_ITA",
		"aid": ["ITA", "IT"],
		"regexp": "[A-Z]{3,3}"
	},
	...
}
```

This term, with [global identifier](gid.md) `iso_3166_1_ITA`, represents the *ISO country code* for *Italy*. It has a [local identifier](lid.md) `ITA` and a *namespace* `iso_3166_1`. 

The [local identifier](lid.md) `ITA` must be *unique* within the *namespace* `iso_3166_1`, no two terms with that *namespace* can have a [local identifier](lid.md) equal to `ITA`.

The [global identifier](gid.md) of the term is the *concatenation* of the *namespace* and the [local identifier](lid.md), separated by an *underscore token* [`_`], the [global identifier](gid.md) is the *unique identifier* of the term *among all namespaces*.

The role of the *namespace* is to group all [local identifiers](lid.md) under a common category.



```json
{
	"term_code": {
		"lid": "iso",
		"gid": "iso",
		"aid": ["iso"]
	},
	...
}
```

This term has no *namespace*, it represents the *top level namespace*, `iso`, of the term in the previous example. When a term has *no namespace* its [global identifier](gid.md) will be equal to its [local identifier](lid.md).

definition.iso_639_3_eng: The unique identifier of the term within its namespace.

description.iso_639_3_eng:
Terms are *uniquely identified* by their [global identifier](gid.md), which is the concatenation of their [namespace](nid.md) *identifier* and *local identifier*, separated by an underscore (`_`) *token*.

The value of this field is used as an *identifier*, so it is required to exclude characters which are not allowed in *variable* or *field* names. The value must also *exclude* the underscore (`_`) *token*, which represents the separator between the [namespace](nid.md) and this field.

This field is *required* and must be *unique* within its [namespace](nid.md), once set, the value *cannot be changed*.

examples.iso_639_3_eng:
```json
{
	"term_code": {
		"nid": "iso_3166_1",
		"lid": "ITA",
		"gid": "iso_3166_1_ITA",
		"aid": ["ITA", "IT"],
		"regexp": "[A-Z]{3,3}"
	},
	...
}
```

This term, with [global identifier](gid.md) `iso_3166_1_ITA`, represents the *ISO country code* for *Italy*. It has a *local identifier* `ITA` and a [namespace](nid.md) `iso_3166_1`. 

The *local identifier* `ITA` must be *unique* within the [namespace](nid.md) `iso_3166_1`, no two terms with that [namespace](nid.md) can have a [local identifier](lid.md) equal to `ITA`.

The [global identifier](gid.md) of the term is the *concatenation* of the [namespace](nid.md) and the *local identifier*, separated by an *underscore token* [`_`], the [global identifier](gid.md) is the *unique identifier* of the term *among all namespaces*.

The role of the *local identifier* is to represent the term code, such as the code of an individual element of a controlled vocabulary. When the *context is set* by the [namespace](nid.md), the *local identifier* becomes the *unique identifier*.



```json
{
	"term_code": {
		"lid": "iso",
		"gid": "iso",
		"aid": ["iso"]
	},
	...
}
```

This term has no [namespace](nid.md), it represents the *top level* [namespace](nid.md), `iso`, of the term in the previous example. When a term has *no* [namespace](nid.md) its [global identifier](gid.md) will be equal to its *local identifier*.
